lines.content: Chrome is a CMI List tracker for everyday use!
It can track Events, Deadlines and simple tasks with
You can add deadlines using a command followed by a description and time.
These will be saved to your Task List
Your deadline will be added to the list alongside a marker
and how many tasks you have in the list
Got it! I've added this task: [D][ ] CS2113 (by: Friday)
Now you have: 3 tasks in the list
- `deadline <description> /<date>` - Adds a task with a deadline.
- `event <description> /<start> /<end>` - Adds an event with a start and end time.
- `find <keyword>` - Searches for tasks containing the keyword.
- `delete <task number>` - Removes a task from the list.
- `mark <task number>` - Marks a task as done.
- `unmark <task number>` - Marks a task as not done.
- `bye` - Exits the program and saves tasks.
- `save` - Saves task list to data directory
* The Chrome class serves as the main controller for the application.
* It initializes the program components such as Storage, Parser, and Ui,
* and implements the main functions of the program such as loading tasks,
* greeting the user, and running the command loop until the user exits.
* Initializes the Storage, Ui, and Parser components of the program.
this.parser = new Parser(new TaskList(toDoList), storage, ui);
* Starts the Chrome program and begins running the command loop.
* Loads tasks from the storage and displays a welcome message.
* Continues running until the user decides to exit.

* Main method to start the Chrome program.
* Creates an instance of Chrome and starts the run method.
* @param args Command-line arguments (not used in this program).
* The Parser class is responsible for processing user input commands.
* It interprets a user input and returns the corresponding method
* in other components of the application such as TaskList, Storage,
* and Ui classes. Commands include adding, marking, deleting,
* and listing tasks, saving the tasks to a file, finding tasks
* @param taskList The TaskList object that holds the list of tasks.
* @param storage The Storage object that handles saving and loading tasks from a file.
* @param ui The Ui object that handles user interface such as exit messages
public Parser(TaskList taskList, Storage storage, Ui ui) {
* Checks whether the program should exit.
* @return true if the program should exit, false otherwise.
* Main method for processing user input.
* It reads the user input and performs actions based on the command.
* The Storage class handles loading and saving tasks to a file.
* It reads tasks from a file, parses them into Task objects,
* and stores them in a list. It also saves the list of tasks
* back to the file in a specific format.
* Initializes the task list and the file path where the tasks will be stored.
* @param filePath The path of the file where the tasks are saved.
* Loads tasks from the file and adds them to the task list.
* If the file does not exist, it will create a new file.
* The tasks are added to the list as Task Objects,
* with error handling for corrupted files.
* Saves the current list of tasks to the file.
private static Task toTask(String line) throws CorruptedFileException {
} catch (DoneException ignored) { // Mark method requires DoneException implementation which is irrelevant here
* Getter method for the list of tasks.
* @return The list of tasks in the storage.
* The TaskList class manages a list of tasks, providing methods to add, mark, unmark, delete, list,
* and search for tasks. It handles task creation, user interaction, and task manipulation operations.
* It is used to manage a collection of Task objects by adding and deleting tasks, marking tasks as done
* or undone, listing all tasks, and finding tasks by keyword.
* Initializes the task list with an existing list of tasks.
* @param tasks The list of tasks to initialize the TaskList with.
* Adds a new task with the specified description to the task list.
* If the task is valid, it is added to the list, and the user is notified.
* If the task description is invalid, an error message is shown.
* @param description The description of the task to be added.
System.out.println(LINE + "\nGot it! I've added this task: "
" task" + plural + " in the list\n" + LINE);
* Lists all tasks currently in the task list.
* Displays each task with an index and prints the task details.
* Marks a specific task as done.
* If the task is already marked as done, a message is shown to the user.
* @param number The task number to be marked as done.
System.out.println(LINE + "\nTask already marked as done\n" + LINE);
System.out.println(LINE + "\nNice! I've marked this task as done:\n"
* Marks a specific task as undone.
* If the task is already marked as undone, a message is shown to the user.
* @param number The task number to be marked as undone.
System.out.println(LINE + "\nTask already marked as undone\n" + LINE);
System.out.println(LINE + "\nOK, I've marked this task as not done yet:\n"
* Deletes a specific task from the list.
* If the task does not exist, a message is shown to the user.
* @param number The task number to be deleted.
System.out.println(LINE + "\nOk . I've removed this task:\n" + task +
"\nYou now have " + count + " task" + plural + " in the list!\n" + LINE);
* Finds and displays tasks that contain the given keyword in their description.
* This method searches through all tasks in the list and prints matching tasks.
* @param input The input containing the keyword to search for (e.g., "find book").
System.out.println("Here are the results for: " + keyword);
* Retrieves a task based on the given input (task number).
* Converts the input into an index and checks for validity (e.g., non-negative, integer).
* @param input The input containing the task number.
* @return The Task object if valid, or null if the task does not exist.
System.out.println(LINE + "\n" + "Number must be 1 or higher" + "\n" + LINE);

* It provides methods to greet the user and exit the program with a farewell message.
